author: dcposch
content: what still needs to happen for calldata to become cheaper? eg via EIP 4488

author: dcposch
content:
here's a concrete example of an dapp that isn't quite feasible at current calldata costs.

i built this last week: https://bitcoinmirror.org/

it mirrors Bitcoin block headers onto Ethereum, allowing efficient SPV proofs. anyone can submit blocks, and the contract just keeps the heaviest chain it's seen.

i deployed to Optimism. the cost works out to ~150k L1 gas per day = about $50-$100 a day currently. if it was 5x cheaper, i'd be happy to just run the submitter indefinitely.

author: timbeiko
content: If it were to happen, we want to have good solutions to provide historical data out of band so that the requirements for running nodes don't go up dramatically. There are a few folks working on this, after which we could then enable EIP-4444

author: dcposch
content:
that sounds important but not urgent, right?

as in: if EIP4488 were to ship soon, then historical data pruning could ship a year later

content: Trying to DM you. Can you accept my friend request?

author: timbeiko
content: Well, 4488 will accelerate the rate at which historical data grows, so we want to have a credible plan to deal with it.

author: dcposch
content:
<@!619138323776012307> sure

<@!552133098075193354> i understand the need for a credible *committment* to deal with it, but even if historical data expiry has some remaining unresolved details, calldata cost reduction seems urgent.

the big narrative of Ethereum is that it's an open platform for dapps.

in the last couple years that narrative has shifted to something more like "it's the most trustworthy settlement layer, and the L2s on top are the new global platform for dapps."

now, in the last three months, we finally have L2. Optimism just removed their whitelist, StarkNet is live etc

...and L2 transactions still cost $10, restricting usage to a small subset of people.

that breaks the narrative. if we wait till we have a perfect story for data expiry to assauge long-term concerns about full-node disk usage, in the meantime we might bleed dapp developers and users to competing chains.

author: Deleted User
content:
Even though the TVL of L2 seems to be increasing according to l2beat, the usage (gas spent) isn't really rising according to: https://dune.xyz/funnyking/L2-Gas-Consumption

author: dcposch
content:
<@456226577798135808>  i think there's a straightforward explanation.

switching has costs. (in particular, for defi protocols, deploying to multiple chains dilutes liquidity.) 

people only switch if the new thing is fundamentally better in some way. competing chains offering transaction costs measured in cents register as "fundamentally better" for many people. Optimism etc don't quite meet that bar given current calldata costs.

we need to fix that as soon as possible.
